title: So, when will we be able to have more options regarding SUMMONER'S NAME?
body:
More accounts are being created everyday, which leaves people with less options when choosing their summoner's name.
Since this game is global why do we have to stick to English letters only?

I personally would like my summoner's name to be written in Arabic letters.

It's unfair for the common language to be English, but it's normal for international affairs to be dealt in a single common language.

Why is it unfair for the common language to be English? Riot is an American company, headquartered in California, and run by primarily English-speakers. It would be weird if the common language wasnt English. 

Just like how I dont chastise Korean companies to do their business in primarily Korean or Russian companies to do their business primarily in Russian, an American company should freely be able to use English as their common language without judgement.
Riot is owned by tencent a Chinese company

Lets be clear about how companies work - Riot is the subsidary, Tenacent is the parent. The parent company has a large say in how much influence they want to impose on the subsidary, whether its a lot or very little. Riot is still headquartered in the United States, run their operations through the United States, and run by Americans. If you wanted to sue Riot, you wouldnt go to China - you would go to California. If you wanted to visit Riot, you wouldnt go to China - you would go to Los Angeles. 

Just because Tenecent owns the majority shares in Riot doesnt take away the "American-ness" of the company. Maybe if they completely revamped their audience, the board, etc the identity of the company would change, but they didnt. Its kinda like the situation Chrysler is in now - are Dodge, Jeeps, and Chrysler American cars? Cause technically they are owned by an Itallian company.
Every company is different. You act like you know what goes on inside of riot

I dont need to know what goes on inside Riot to know where their place of incorporation, their headquarters, or their CEO is - thats all public information that you file with the state. I dont know how much influence Tenecent decides to exercise over Riot, but Riot still operates out of California.
Which is the most important thing to know...

Why is it important?

If, hypothetically, Tenecent controls everything, what difference does it make? Riot is still headquartered in Los Angeles. Riot is still incorporated in California. Brandon Beck is still the CEO, and Mark Merrill is still the President. The LCS is still a limited liability company who is organized in Delaware. Riot has to adhere to California laws, are subject to lawsuits in California, and pay their taxes to California. Even if Tenecent controls everything, Riot is still an American company. Its an American company with Chinese ownership.

Yea, Tencent bought Riot (an American company) and left them in control of the process due to it's success.

They did fuck us with earning money though (no discounts on new skins).

Read again, I said "international affairs".
This game is a tiny detail, I'm talking about economy and politics.
There should be a single international language, but it can't be a previously existent one.

Youre in a League of Legends board in a thread talking about Riot and the languages they use. If you want to talk about something thats completely beyond the scope of anything discussed in the thread, you better be sure than you mention it. I had no idea that in a League of Legends board you decided to talk about politics and international affairs of nations. 

And I dont see why a standard international languages cant be a previously existent one. Whats so wrong with that? Is there something inherently wrong with an existing written language that makes it unusable? Theres no point in creating an entirely new language just for communication in international affairs when there are perfectly fine ones already existing.

We don't necessarily need a new language... but let's be honest, it's not a bad idea. Super complicated and a bit difficult to implement fully, but you could actually make a sensible language without all the garbage that comes with current languages. 

Just look at English as an example - it's freaking retarded! Not even native speakers know how to speak it correctly. 

Somebody go make a language that actually makes sense and doesn't have tons of exceptions to every rule, arbitrary rules that just make it more complicated to speak (formal language that some languages have, for example), and overlapping words and pronunciations. Please.

I think there are pros and cons to having a separate new language for International Affairs. 

On one hand, I can see it completely overtaking our "natural" languages. If this new "superlanguage" is the only langauge that matters in international affairs, I can see it becoming the primary language worldwide. Our language and dialects are part of our culture, no matter where you are in the world. This might homogenize our world, which I dont know if is a good thing or not. 

On the other hand, I can also see it being strictly used for international affairs and nothing else. Then IA would be a separate kind of discussion for only the few educated elite - I would no longer be able to understand what the leaders from my own country are saying, and would have to rely on a translator. When I hear an English-speaker speak on an international level, its a lot easier to get their message when listening to them directly. 
______________

The problem is that Language isnt like math. Even in the same language you get adaptions, changes to dialect, changes to pronunciation, and changes to meaning. Language is first and foremost a method of communication - as long as the message is understood by others, the language "works". But because of that, Language is fluid. When languages first developed, do you think they had all these arbitrary rules? Of course not. but over time, the languages adapt, whether it was to incorporate a region and therefore create a new dialect, to borrow a new word from another language, or sometimes just because it sounds good. 

Even if you attempt to create a formal language with no arbitrary rules, overlapping words, or anything else, it wont stay that way.

The world is already homogenizing due to technology - media, transportation, communication, etc. The discussion that needs to happen is: Is homogenization a bad thing? Would losing parts of cultures really be that bad for humanity? Would it be worth it for the entire human race to be unified in a single, global culture?

If you think about it, despite the idealism of preserving cultural identities and keeping traditions alive, most of the major conflicts of the world throughout history have been between - and largely due to - different cultures. Just look at the huge conflict between ISIS and Western civilization right now. 

Language unifies - but it also separates. Ancient Rome referred to the Germanic tribes and others as "barbarians" and looked on them with contempt simply because they did not speak Latin. That was actually the root of the term "barbarian", coming from "bar-bar", the equivalent of today's "blah-blah-blah" - referring to the way their language sounded to the Romans. One of the issues with illegal Hispanic immigration in the US is the language barrier and the fact that many immigrants don't learn English. It limits their options and their ability to contribute to society and so paints a negative picture for native English speakers.

A common language certainly won't solve everything, but it's a step in the right direction. And it certainly won't stay the same forever, but it would be more stable than the languages we have now. We can see even now that languages are far more stable than in the past, where the language could change slightly even from one village to the next (despite being one "unified" nation, Spain actually has 3 separate languages). With a governing body to regulate a new language, it would stay stable for a very long time, especially with regards to its structure and grammar.

And don't forget - there has never been a language that was "created" by a group of people who set out with the intent to do so. All languages have gradually evolved from other languages through dialects and vernacular in particular areas. All of them inherited inconsistencies and arbitrariness from at least one, and often many (looking at you, English), other languages. 

A language that was crafted by a group of specialists with the intention to last indefinitely and fulfill all of our communication needs could endure for a very, very long time.

You know, youre right - the world is homogenizing. Which is also why you probably see so much pushback, through terrorist organizations like ISIS who stay firm to their beliefs. If the world wasnt homogenizing toward "western" values, I dont think organizations like ISIS exist. Again, I dont know if homogenization is a good thing or not. Culture is unique and underappreciated. People in America, especially those of African-American descent, seem to put a lot of emphasis on culture and their lack thereof. Whether its really that important? I dont know. 

I appreciate your thoughts that a single created language can endure. I actually think it might be possible - when "separate" languages like C++ exist in the programming world, they seem to endure. Of course, a spoken word is a lot more complex, but in theory it can happen. Whether or not it will endure? I guess you can only tell by doing it, because youre venturing into a new territory. (As a side note, I dont know why you single out English for having inconsistencies or arbitrary rules. Every language has inconsistencies, especially if they survive for a long time. English is nothing new.)

I single out English because it seems to have more inconsistencies than most other languages and is also my native language, so I can tell how stupid it is more easily than other languages. Learning other languages, they are much more logical and consistent. Not completely, but more than English.

Because it creates a power relationship, or rather, the preexisting language gets picked based on power relationships.
The US enslaves the rest of the world, which is why we're speaking English.

If you want the reason _we_ are speaking English, its because of the British Empire. The US has only gotten into being a world power after WWI, about a hundred years ago. The United Kingdom was controlling the world since the 1500s. And remember, prior to the formation of the United States as a separate nation and our Revolutionary War, we were also controlled by the British. 

And whats wrong with power relationships? Youre talking about International Affairs. Part of International Affairs is the power relationships between nations. What - you think that if we create a separate language for IA, suddenly every country becomes a world power? You think the powerful countries are willing to give up their status? Get real dude.
